problem.p: A block of mass m is attached to a horizontal spring of force constant k. At time t = 0, the block has a speed [mathjaxinline]v_o[/mathjaxinline] and the spring is stretched an amount [mathjaxinline]x_o[/mathjaxinline] from its equilibrium position as shown in the figure.
Given that [mathjaxinline]v_o=\omega x_o[/mathjaxinline], where \(\omega \) is the angular frequency of oscillation, how long does it take for the block to be momentarily at rest for the 1st time?
What is the amplitude of the oscillation?

Dividing (eq.3) by (eq.4) we obtain: \(\tan\phi=x_o\omega/v_o \). Using that \(v_o=x_o\omega_o\), then \(\tan\phi=1\), therefore \(\phi=\pi/4\)

As a result, the velocity as a function of time is given by \(v(t)=A\omega\cos(\omega t + \pi/4) \). The block has zero velocity for the first time when \( \cos(\omega t+\pi/4)=0 \), or when \( \omega t+\pi/4 = \pi/2\). Therefore, \(\omega t = \pi/4\) or \(t = \pi/(4\omega)\)

Use (eq. 3) and \(\phi=\pi/4\) to get \(A = \sqrt(2)x_o \). Another way of obtaining the amplitude is to use conservation of mechanical energy. Try it! Use the given initial conditions to obtain the amplitude of oscillation. The value of \(\phi\) is not needed in this approach.
